For the month of February, I read the book The Third Chimpanzee. This book details human evolution from the anthropological perspective, something I am very interested in. The book is broken up into five different sections that detail different aspects of humanity and evolution, beginning with our leap from apes to humans. I first picked up this book because I thought it would focus on early hominids but this book discusses so much more than that. Human evolution has not just been biological processes, but culture ones as well. The author takes the time to detail three of humanities most successful attributes, art, language and agriculture, as well as three of its most destructive, addiction, environmental degradation and genocide.A very important section of this book is the one that explains how humans have conquered the globe and how Europeans came to conquer most other humans. Despite what Europeans have taught for hundreds of years, they are no better or smarter than any other humans on the planet. Europeans evolved more quickly than other people solely because of their geography and I think this is an important lesson to learn for AmeriCorps. The lesson is that all humans are the same, no one is better than anyone else and it is important for us to know that because Minnesota is extremely diverse. Also, many of the people we work with face hardships because of where they are from or the color of their skin, they are considered “others” and it is much easier for humans to torment people that they consider “others.” I feel most AmeriCorps members already know this but it is important to reiterate because I know we all have a tendency to forget. Also, I am the kind of person who needs to know why things are they way they are. This book helped me see that and I know I will be more aware of what I say and how I teach from now on.This book dispels many of the myths about humanity and shows how closely related we still are to animals, and to one another. I would suggest this book to anyone as curious as myself or anyone interested in anthropology because it portrays many of the things we already know in a new light, plus it includes lots more interesting facts. I believe strongly in learning from the past to make a better future and you can’t get much more past than all of human history, but that is just me.

It doesn't mean that I didn't learn anything from this book, so I start with what I have learned:- A great deal of information about how homo sapiens developed from apes, the differences between our ancestors (cro-magnon) and other H.sapiens species.- Very interesting information on the development of language and the links among different languages.- Natural selection vs. sexual selection. I found the notion of sexual selection very intriguing and got the answers to some questions I had in mind about human races.Why I didn't like the book:I have recently started studying evolution, so I am pretty new in the subject. Starting the book, I was very excited, however, I lost my excitement all together after the first two chapters. There are lots of claims without enough back up evidence or reasonable arguments to prove it. For example, in two chapters, the author explains why human has private sex or why adultery exists based on this claim that humans are monogamous. However, he specified only one paragraph with a feeble argument on why human are evolutionary monogamous. In another example, in chapter "alone in a crowded universe", he claims that humans are unique and alone in the whole universe. Now, in 2017, we know that is probably not true and yes! the book was written 20 years ago. But, just the fact that an evolutionary biologists (if we can call him that) brings up such a huge claim related to astronomy makes me think twice about his other claims.The other thing that made the book intolerable for me was that he tries to explain everything based on evolution and the links to other animal behaviors. It seems that he ignores the role of culture in human behavior all together. He argues that making art or drug/alcohol consumption are evolutionary adopted behavior (especially by males) to attract mates. Such a claim needs more evidence than just explaining one bird's (bower bird) tendency to make beautiful and artistic nests (Chapter: the origin of art). there are experiments showing that laboratory mice get addicted to cocaine and prefer to be awarded drug instead of food or water. It seems that mice find the pleasure of drug consumption and get addicted to it. It is not for sexual attraction.

After reading "Collapse," I encountered former Stanford President Donald Kennedy and asked him about Professor Diamond: "Brilliant, but he overreached." At the moment, I thought Dr. Kennedy was being too dismissive, but now I realize he was speaking about "The Third Chimpanzee," Dr. Diamond's first book."The Third Chimpanzee" serves as a tour de force. Jared Diamond's scholarship in evolution, experience in New Guinea and deep understanding of geography, as it should be taught, yielded a book which substantiates all that it can and speculates on what in unknown with piercing insight.Basically, the text looks at humans as a space alien would: a branch of chimpanzees. He shows the precursors to human behavior, unusual aspects of human sexuality, and guesses that what allowed us to "leap forward" 40,000 years ago was the ability to speak with grammar (other animals speak). The leaping forward still retained animal behavior, however; which can be problematic.His final chapters focus on genocide, the unwitting overuse of natural resources and extinction.His concerns in 1992, never mentioned global warming or "unusual" climate change; because there was no need! Civilizations have disappeared before due to environmental mismanagement. Diamond doesn't suffer the fools who think that humans were environmentalists before Western expansion.If I may add my thought, to what should be a must read: the focus on climate change is itself hiding from the truth of what we are. We need to find ways of just not bettering ourselves, but those we see as the other; remembering that the other isn't so sweet either. The focus on group vs group or men vs women etc is truly a dead-end. The pathway to long-term environmental management eludes us currently. We need calmness with clarity in direction.

Diamond attempts to chart a history of humans - drawing from many fields including anthropology, archeology, linguistics, as well as zoology, he provides an interesting and entertaining synthesis. He attempts to show links between humans and our closest relatives, the other two chimpanzees" as well as other humans, attempting to explain how we diverged in the past and where we may eventually end up as a species. Readers of Diamond's other work will see how he has expanded on his ideas in other books (the reason for European dominance in Guns, Germs and Steel, how societies collapse (for example those on Easter Island and in Chaco Canyon) in Collapse. Of course a lot of this is conjecture, but there is not much alternative (it is not like there are well chronicled accounts of early human history), and Diamond's conjectures are well reasoned.In many ways, his central thesis is that human history took an eventful turn with our ability to master language. In many ways, this is largely undisputed - similar theories are espoused by Harari in Sapiens. But Diamond's account is slightly broader than Harari's in that he goes back to trace the divergence from our chimpanzee ancestor, whereas Harari's account was an excellent summary of human societal history once we had developed the ability to master language. Actually I found that one of The Third Chimpanzee's weak points - it was slightly too broad and light on details. In particular, especially with the benefit of having read Diamond's books published after this, a lot of this felt liked slightly underdone. But again I stress that is only with the benefit of having read Diamond's other works, so perhaps it is slightly unfair. In summary an interesting read, but for those who have the time I would recommend them go directly to Diamond's works which he published after these.

Human beings have always liked to think of themselves as special. We are unique. We are distinctive in our actions, our bodies, our minds or our souls. The human animal is unparalleled among the creatures of Earth. Perhaps we are peculiar in all the known universe. Is it because of something in our genes, the very DNA that produces life, that we are rare? Or does it have to do with our ability to use language. The remarkable thing about us may be our minds; its ability to realize we exist and others exist separate from us. Possibly the miracle is a spark from some divine creator. We can see this belief in our mythology, our theology, and even in our early development and psychology. Perhaps what makes us different is not something special but something darker. Our propensity to hurt ourselves or others; to the point we are capable of destroying all life on our small blue globe.So what, exactly, is it that does make us special? What is it that makes us different - some would even say better or more important - than the rest of all life on our planet? Are we, in fact, special at all or our we just another - albeit less harry - chimpanzee? Not even a great ape but just another in a long line of upright standing mammal?This is the question Jared Diamond asks in 
The Third Chimpanzee: The Evolution and Future of the Human Animal
. He asks it not with metaphysics or theology but with biology, geography and social science. He questions our unique construction, the places we live and how we interact; both inter-species and intraspecies, and which of these key components that can be measured may - or may not - either separately or in combination be the key that makes us human.I’ve read the other two books in what is colloquially known as Dr. Diamonds’ “trilogy”. With 
Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies
 and 
Collapse: How Societies Choose to Fail or Succeed
 Dr. Diamond expounds on the questions asked in this book. In Guns, Germs and Steel he concentrates on the geography of why human society, Western Eurasian society in particular, has spread across the globe. What was it that allowed European technology to flourish while African and American societies were hindered in their progress. Utilizing geography he demonstrates it was not any inherent superiority in the Europeans themselves but rather a quirk of good geographic luck. The wide open plains and steppe of Europe and Central Asia allowed the development of agriculture and animal husbandry; and hence advanced society, sooner in Eurasia. Likewise the sweeping continent allowed technological advances as well as disease to spread easily. Thus providing faster distribution of knowledge and immunity to a wider array of illness.Collapse focuses on the social and environmental impact of the human species on both itself and the the world in which we live. Looking at societies from Indonesia, Mesoamerica, South Pacific Islands and even Africa, Dr. Diamond demonstrates human beings often act shortsightedly. We fail to see or wantonly ignore the damage we are responsible for until it is to late. Often the damage takes a long time to accrue; as in the fertile crescent or Petra, once the breadbasket of the Middle East. It can also happen within a few generations, as on small South Pacific islands; where the new human arrivals use up scarce resources. The effects of human intervention, either ignored or mistaken, often last long after those who caused the damage have moved on or perished.The germs (if you’ll excuse the pun) of these ideas are found in The Third Chimpanzee. Dr. Diamond dedicates this book to, who at the time were small boys, his two young sons. He hopes that by trying to examine whether it is biology - the small 2% difference in DNA- or sociology - our use of language or development of society or propensity to hurt ourselves or others - which makes us more than just apes. With each exploration he shows we are not unique. Other animals use some form of language; tool use, while not wide spread, is there with other animals, even beyond primates. Even our use of drugs to our own detriment is not unique, and the trait we most abhor, the purposefully killing of another is practiced by other creatures as well. It seems we are different not in kind but only in quantity to the rest of the animal kingdom. We seem to have the broadest vocabulary of all animals. Humans create the largest impact on the environment. We, and only we, have the ability to completely wipe ourselves from the face of the Earth. With his exploration of our similarities to the rest of the animal kingdom, Dr, Diamond has hope that we can learn. That we are able to see our similarities as well as our distinctiveness and embrace our true position in the universe. As the third chimpanzee.If we look at our psychological development as individuals it seems to mirror the journey the human race has taken in its own understanding of our place in the universe. Starting out we are the end all and be all of existence. The sun rises and sets for us and about us. As we grow we start to see that there are other creatures around, but surely they can’t be anywhere near as important as we are. Later, some of us at least, come to realize that there are others and they are just as important as we are. The world does not revolve around us but we interact with a much larger world. If we are very lucky we discover that we really see some of these others as more important than ourselves. So important their continued existence is worth more to us than anything - including our own. These are the people we claim to love, honor, revere and cherish.If, as Dr. Diamond hopes throughout this book and the rest of his “trilogy”, we can learn to see beyond our simple means we can embrace not our uniqueness but our connection to the rest of the world. Then, perhaps, we will see this connection does not diminish us but broadens who we are as both species and individual. We can see that as a unique part of a greater whole we have a duty and a responsibility to think beyond or selfishness to the greater good.

Another fantastic book by Jared Diamond, but chronologically it is one of his earlier books and several chapters in this one one are definitely the inspirations for his future books - particularly "Guns, Germs & Steep" and "Collapse" - so this is the nucleus of some amazing follow-up books!Here, he makes a very thorough (albeit slightly dated - this book WAS written in 1991 after all) analysis on evolution of our species and how genetically similar we are to our two closest living 'cousins', the common & pygmy chimps. I found this section of the book the most fascinating and interesting. The book goes on to how societies developed, proposing a very interesting thought at some point about whether we as humans were better off as hunter-gatherers than when we developed agriculture, society and so on (well, perhaps we wouldn't be prosecuting or exterminating people different than us, but I personally quite appreciate that we developed writing and I can read/listen to books like this). Other parts of the book then continue on to make the arguments which he has fleshed out in follow up books (why Eurasians society/language conquered the 'new world', and how some older societies collapsed) , before ending the book on chapters related to how we are really causing the destruction of our own future due to illogical actions.Either way, if you are a fan of Jared's other books obviously I do not need to recommend this book. But I also highly recommend it especially if you liked the more 'up-to-date' (albeit in my opinion, not as well researched) 'Sapiens' by Yuval Noah Harari.

This probably would have been four stars had I read it when it came out, but the science is about 25 years old at this point. It's a good book, all in all, and has that particular Jared Diamond-y flair for being really empathetic, gloomy, but ultimately offering optimism. I thought it would be more about evolution but he spends quite a bit of time on many of the concepts he also covers in Guns Germs and Steel and Collapse (which I am familiar with so this was not new). His affection for the New Guineans he talks so much about in those other two books comes through here as well. There are chapters on the spread of the Indo European language and culture (great one!), the origins of behaviors and cultural complexity when compared to other animals, and human migration. He also spends an inordinate amount of page space on xenophobia, habitat destruction and environmental collapse, extinction, genocide, and the importance of specific resources that allowed our species to conquer the planet. None of these are unworthy topics, however, I was hoping for some more information about evolution, biology, our earliest ancestors and stone age through iron age history, rather than ending as it does on an environmental / sixth extinction type diatribe. Nevertheless, lots of valuable information, and as always, Jared's unique voice and perspective come through clearly. Read it if you like his other books.

This book is really broad, kind of impressive in scope. The organization is reasonably good for covering such far-ranging topics. There were some topics that I found particularly interesting and novel, such as the idea that sexual selection played a large role in skin color and it’s not entirely a result of proximity to the equator. I also really enjoyed the part about what geographical features could have given some civilizations on earth a head start (teaser for the later Guns Germs and Steel). From cross vs self-pollinating staple grains to the axis the civilization travels along, there’s a lot to consider. However the tone of the book is a little unscientific and overly-confident. It has the patriarchal air of a Victorian grandpa sitting you upon his knee to tell you his pet theories about the world and expecting your rapt attention because this is the first time you’ve heard any of this. The chapter about the human use of potentially harmful drugs struck me as especially rich in unfounded stretching speculation (it’s to show off our handicaps) and deep sanctimony. Also, does anyone else get the feeling he’s just dying to show you his vacation photos from New Guinea even though no one asked to see them? This is actually my first Diamond book, so perhaps he has since improved on this aspect of his writing. I’ll probably read Guns Germs and Steel next, since I found those topics from this book especially interesting.

The sheer breadth of the book is impressive, he easily could have written this as three separate books... oh wait, he later did (Guns, Germs, and Steel; Why is Sex Fun?; Collapse). So there is a fair bit of retread if you're familiar with his other works but it's not as repetitive as reading multiple Dawkins books because he has so many varying ideas. Diamond's arguments lie on a gradient from inspired (more animal domestication happened in Eurasia not the Americas because it was easier to spread longitudinally than latitudinally) to arse-pulling (explanation for why drug addiction is a thing). But generally enjoyable. The later chapters such as "the Golden Age that Never Was" is hugely depressing, showcasing how long the anthropogenic mass extinction currently underway has been going on. I knew about the evidence of human-caused large mammal and bird extinctions in North America and Australasia, but I don't think I've encountered such a list of examples as in this book. It creates a damning picture for the human species: if we were responsible for the loss of so many species when we were small in number wielding spear technology, what hope do we possibly have in the highly-impacted, resource-stressed environment we find ourselves? Probably not much, so I guess do what you can and appreciate the wonders of nature still among us.

Once again, Diamond goes deep on the topic that seems to intrigue us all; ourselves. With his unusual mixture of insight and humor, he explores and explains our evolutionary behavior, origins and our species domination of the planet. After all, with chapter headings such as The Science of Adultery, Why Do We Grow Old and Die?, Agriculture's Mixed Blessings,and The Golden Age That Never Was, how can the curious reader be anything but intrigued? I found his comprehensive exploration of the origins and development of human language to be particularly compelling, probably because I had never considered what an impactful evolutionary step language was to the success of Homo sapiens. Diamond is an excellent writer as well as an insightful scientist and keeps even the untutored science devotee anxious for his next factual observation. This is an early book for the award-winning author (1993) and in the beginning, I had issue with some of his conclusions on human and primate relationships that more recent DNA analysis has called into question but at the end of the volume, he covers some of these topics under the heading: "New Discoveries". I've become a real Jerod Diamond fan and if you give him a try I think you will be too.

Although a bit dry during parts, this is a good introduction to anthropology. Although it would be impossible to recount all the information Diamond presents upon a first reading, his writing links human behaviors and origins together in a chain of associations so that one fact logically leads to another, making it much easier to recall the story of human development as a whole. I chose this book because of a marginal interest I had in anthropology and because I know that Diamond is a very popular science author, and he did not disappoint, even though this is his first book. When I pick up another one of his texts, I hope to see the same witty tone I found in this one.If you consider yourself to be the ultimate champion of political correctness, then try not to get offended- this 1992 book discusses human sexuality (among other traits) in objective, binary terms that do not glorify women, with no mention of homosexuality. For all the rest of you, give it a go. I'd recommend this book to anyone who is substantially interested in anthropology or the origins of universal human qualities.

Even reading this so long after its publication, some of the topics and ideas still seem novel and interesting (e.g. discussions on sexual selection as perhaps better explanations for certain human traits that are frequently attributed to other factors), and others seem very prescient for the time that the book was written.It’s a little bit difficult to separate ideas and theories that are supported by a lot of evidence from those that are more “pet speculations”. I had already read “Guns, Germs, and Steel” when I started “The Third Chimpanzee”. He rehashes and extrapolates on a lot of the most interesting parts of “The Third Chimpanzee” in “Guns, Germs, and Steel”, so I would recommend skipping this book and reading that instead. “Sapiens” is sort of an updated version of this book and might be a better choice for a similar subject matter now. Although, it may be a fun exercise to read both and see how the thinking in this area has and hasn’t changed in the last quarter century.

“There is nothing new about prophecies to the effect that the end of the world is near if we do not repent. What is new is that such a prophecy is now true, for two obvious reasons. First, nuclear weapons give us the means to wipe ourselves out quickly: no humans possessed this means before. Second, we already appropriate about forty per cent of the Earth’s net productivity (that is, the net energy captured from sunlight). With the world’s human population now doubling every forty-one years, we will soon have reached the biological limit to growth, at which point we will have to start fighting each other in deadly earnest for a slice of the world’s fixed pie of resources. In addition, given the present rate at which we are exterminating species, most of the world’s species will become extinct or endangered within the next century, but we depend on many species for our own life support.”

Jared Diamond provides riveting insights into the anthropological and geological perspectives on human interaction with the world. The Third Chimpanzee outlines what makes us more or less different from our close genetic relatives. In general, the unique impact of humans is more of a technological difference than one of unique capacities. Even more interesting is that you see the beginnings of Jared Diamond's most popular book, Guns, Germs, and Steel, in the final chapters of this book. This is where he begins to outline what became one of the most interesting takes on why humans spread across the world as they did. I also appreciated Jared Diamond's take on the role of humans on the extinction of flora and fauna and that there is good reason to believe that this was always the case wherever homo sapiens traversed. Highly recommended for those interested in anthropology, archeology, and geology and what it can tell us about our history as a species.

Recently purging my bookshelves I hesitated over this unread title, not sure if a science book written in 1992 would still be relevant over 25 years later. And though I'm sure my ignorance of current research helped, I wasn't bothered by the book's age. Diamond makes his subject matter so readable, detailed enough to satisfy my curiosity without descending into dry tedium. I loved the section tracing the history of the Proto-Indo-European language (who knew their was a field called linguistic paleontology?). Some sections rehashed the theories of Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies, which was still enjoyable as a refresher to that work.I would normally not have a work of non-fiction on my nightstand, but this was fun to dip into every night for a few weeks.

Diamond demonstrates a remarkable breadth of knowledge and even if you don't full buy into his thesis (success of a species or ethnic group or nation is based on luck), you have to admire his ability to write in an engaging manner and continually challenge the reader. Just a few many interesting theories in the book:- Diamond maintains that one reason Neanderthals did not develop more quickly and innovate was that life expectancy was so short that they did not benefit from the "grandparent effect," where older generations help teach younger how things were, and suggest how things can be with innovation.- Diamond pushes a sub-thesis of his book, which is that the development of agriculture has not been a total win for human society (much less other species). He spends a lot of time offering evidence of the benefits of the hunter-gatherer society.

This is the kind of book I was hoping for when I picked up Sapiens. It speaks specifically about our evolutionary climb from our common ape ancestor and covers the impact we've had on our environment, other species, and ourselves without becoming too philosophical or employing pages of math. It also ends on a note of hope, which is nice. I think the hope is a bit optimistic and unrealistic, but it's still nice. The book is, however, a product of its time. There are some casual uses of words that are now acknowledged to be racial slurs, and some science that has since been altered, but overall, this was an absolutely fascinating look at where we come from, and should serve as a bit of a reality check for those who deny that we're just smart animals with fine motor skills. A "gift" to this planet we are not.

This started out really interesting - the discussions of language, genetic similarity, trait evolution, and sexual differentiation were all very interesting, even with my pre-existing knowledge of anthropology. The final third of the book, however, was judgemental, damning, excessively pessimistic. Yes, the world is a tire fire, and yes we caused it, but the contempt that Diamond has for the human race seemed useless and needlessly strident. Given that some of the science in this is dated - for instance, we now know that most people of European descent carry Neanderthal genes, despite his assertions that he thought it unlikely - and given that many of his conclusions seem based a little too heavily on his own opinion, I don't know if I'd recommend this. Instead, I would suggest choosing something with more updated science.

The Third Chimpanzee is an amazing work of science and erudition which no intelligent human being should even consider missing. Differently from the generic approach, Diamond tries to explain human evolution not only from a biological and genetic perspective but rather likes to connect biogenetics to the social aspect of our species progress through time. Furthermore his writing is peppered with cool facts which are often used to complement an argument and render it more interesting while giving it much wider perspective.What sort of man/woman do you find attractive and why?Why human males have the largest penis of all apes? Why do chimps have the largest testes?What's the evolutionary reason for menopause?How unique are humans in the universe?These are just a select few of the questions that will be answered - compellingly and argumentatively - while you read. The Third Chimpanzee is a goldmine of creativity. Just like Diamond did in Guns, Germs and Steel he provides original and often novative explanations to the reasons humans evolved the way they did. While GGS is more concerned with the adaptation of man after the major biological evolution had already occurred, TTC concerns itself with evolution at a larger scale at a both biological and social perspective. Most importantly Diamond is able to merge those aspects and therefore you don’t feel like you are reading a choppy and fragmented book but rather an integral and creative approach to evolution which although at times might feels not hardly grounded into fact (not because of a lack of wanting but because it is impossible to conduct practical experiments with human evolution), definitely sounds thought out and rational and well-researched.Now sure, some arguments may not fully convince you (the woodpecker/radios analogy was hard to accept for me), however, even when they sound too far fetched, Diamond does his best to make them engaging, interesting and most importantly continuously supported by real-world facts and examples.It is impossible to not create a web of connections with what you already know while reading. For example I found a number of interesting similarities between the modern sworn virgins of Northern Albania and Papua New Guinea’s specificity of cultural evolution. And then 10 pages after finding that kind of connection I found an actual reference to Albania proper: "Anyone with time, money and desire can visit almost any country except for a few xenophobic exceptions, such as Albania and North Korea” - Kindle location 3607. However remember that this was written in 1991 (although I believe the republished 2006 version should have corrected this).It is obvious that there is some overlapping and repetition if you have read any of the other books by Diamond. So far I have only read GGS and have found a number of ideas and chapters resembling parts of that other masterpiece by Diamond - especially chapters 14 and 18 - however if you space the books some months apart you will find that the repetition will serve as a welcome reminder and review of the dense material.Like with GGS, I especially love Diamond's arguments on language development, diffusal and replacement. However I would argue that even though, say indo-European languages came from the same proto-indo-European language, the entropic process of dialects and language variations has produced languages as different as Albanian, Celtic and Indian, and giving it time will continue to do so in geometric progression. In retrospect it might be possible that language evolved only once, and then entropied into our current state - I believe this to be a fascinating illustration of some universal entropic patterns found everywhere in the universe. However since limited contact is a prerequisite for language entropy, a more globalized world might certainly slow if not stop the entropic process of language evolution. TLDR of this paragraph is DO NOT for any reason miss chapter 15 - it is just astounding.Conclusively, even the bibliography is amazingly put-together. The research for each chapter is narratively detailed and broken down. This book is a golden mine of creativity and inspiration, not only about human evolution, but about the universe in general. Diamond’s work inspires me.

This is the third book I've read by Jared Diamond, and though I didn't think it was as groundbreaking as Guns, Germs, and Steel and Collapse, I still enjoyed the book. In fact, the ideas that were fleshed out in those two books (Why the European Culture came to dominate the world in the 19th century and why societies collapse) are both present in their infancies in this book.Basically, Diamond makes the case that man is nothing more than another chimpanzee. We share over 98% of our DNA with chimps, and Diamond shows that everything we consider to be uniquely human traits have animal precursors or equivalents (with the possible exception of drug abuse). Sure humans use tools, but so do some animals (such as chimps using sticks to get termites). Well, humans have language another person might say. So does a species of monkey Diamond discusses that have different vocalizations for eagles, leopards, and snakes. Humans lie! Diamond mentions that some of these monkeys will vocalize a leopard warning when their tribe is losing a fight with another tribe to send their rivals scurrying up trees.The list continues! Diamond showed that bower birds create "art" and that various animals commit "murder" and even genocide. He also speaks of how ants have domesticated aphids and use them as a food source, thus having a kind of agriculture. In fact, the only thing that seems to be uniquely human is drug abuse, and even that seems to have some animal precursors.Diamond's main point is that humans have clearly evolved from animals and that the dividing line that we tend to draw between ourselves and animals isn't as distinct as we'd like to think. In fact, almost all the behaviors that we consider to be uniquely human appear to have animal equivalents, or at least precursors.The next section of the book spends time detailing the evolution of man from our separation from a common ancestor with chimps and gorillas 7 million years ago to the arrival of Cro-Magnon Man 40,000 years ago. The speculation about the extinction of the Neanderthals being caused by Cro-Magnon Man is convincing and the discussion of the spread of languages is interesting as well.Diamond also takes some time to point out the flaws in the Drake Equation that predicts a universe teeming with intelligent life. The best part is when Diamond makes a compelling case that if we really thought there was intelligent life out there then we should try to avoid it as our history tells us that when two groups of humans meet the technologically superior group wipes out the other. So sending out a radio broadcast telling whoever is out there exactly where we are probably wasn't the best idea ever.Finally the rest of the book presents some early ideas of Diamond's that were expanded in Guns, Germs, and Steel and Collapse. If you've read those two books, you'll find some of this repetitive, but the first half of the book more than makes up for it and a little redundancy never hurt anyone.I guess my only other qualm is that Diamond tends to over exaggerate at times. He has a tendency to make statements like "This evidence is indisputable" or "This theory is unquestionable" which is obviously false. A theory that is not questionable is not a theory. I agree 100% with the majority of Diamond's theories and conclusions, but that does not mean that they should be beyond questioning. We should remember what Norbert Wiener knew at the age of 10 when he wrote of "the impossibility of man being certain of anything".

There’s just something about how Jared Diamond writes his explanatory prose that it clicks with me. Like myself, the polymath author loves delving deep into scientific subject matters that pique his interest. Granted, I only have a cursory interest in birds, but Third Chimpanzee is mostly about human evolution as described by the field of Biological Anthropology. I love digesting information on human evolution. And yes, I will be heaping lots of praise onto this book.Third Chimpanzee surprised me. It’s not only a treatise on the biological evolution of our species. It also delves into the evolution of our language trees, how our sexual taboos evolved with our sexual practices, and how agriculture adversely impacted our organism. The multifaceted aspects make the entire volume so rich in content, all of which is extremely well-researched for its time. Diamond is an accomplished & comprehensive academic, thus when he says he has “done lots of research” (an eye-rolling phrase often used these days to connote confirmation bias masturbation), he actually engages with empiricism and scrutiny of hypotheses. Diamond understands when evidence for a position is tenuous, and when it’s overwhelmingly strong. The aspects regarding the evolution of our organism certainly fall under the latter. Diamond does exceptional work in Third Chimpanzee of not only detailing the aspects from multiple angles, but he does so with such accessible flair of his prose that it’s a treat to read.I find Diamond, in each of his novels written for a general audience, intentionally adds something new and refreshing to capture the reader’s imagination and tickle their fancy. He doesn’t rehash arguments that have been discussed to death just because he needs to feed his ego by stressing what he considers a novel point of view. He doesn’t provide a plodding summary of the paradigms in the field, akin to a textbook in novel form that certain science communicators tend to sell. He doesn’t overextend the length of his novels so that it provides a comprehensive analysis that cannot be assailed. His taut analysis of the various topics can be assailed with criticisms. I for one was amused by his self-contradiction when it came to evaluating threats posed by potential extra-terrestrials: he previously described how we shouldn’t draw conclusions from a dataset of one (we have a dataset of zero for aliens), then goes on to assume advanced aliens will undoubtedly be detrimental to us because our species provides multiple instances of advanced civilizations devastating less advanced ones. It’s a rare intellectually lazy point by Diamond, and lacks nuance. Strangely enough, in his book Collapse, Diamond details how the advanced USA’s interactions with the less advanced feudal Japan in the later 1800s brought a mixed bag of good and bad for the Japanese. Nevertheless, it’s a minor quibble, and nobody searches out Diamond for expertise on Sociology.In its essentials, Third Chimpanzee is taut, compelling, and stimulating. Where it lacks in nuance, it makes up for in challenging ingrained perceptions of supposed superiority & uniqueness of geography, lifestyles, and behaviors of the creatures we call human being. It's interesting we don't refer to each other as primates, even though there are numerous valid arguments that we haven't abandoned much that defines the order.
