Jared Diamond is a professor at my alma mater UCLA, and he became famous outside the science world after the success of 'Guns, Germs and Steel', which apart from winning him Pulitzer, also made him a very wealthy man. This book was written several years before that mega-bestseller. 1992, to be exact. But it contains several ideas and themes that would later be borne more fully in GG&S. In fact, he even uses the phrase 'guns, germs and iron' later in the book when he touches upon the subject of conquests throughout the world. 'The Third Chimpanzee' is a very ambitious book. In it Diamond sets out to trace the long and complicated history of human evolution. The wonderful odyssey of Homo Sapiens from Australopithecus to Erectus to Neanderthalis is told with a great flourish. He examines this from several different angles: genetics, behavior, language, arts, war, agriculture, addiction, anthropology and genocide. The titular third chimpanzee refers to us humans. Using genetics Diamond argues that humans are so similar to chimpanzees that we should really be classed as the third chimpanzee species (or conversely, the two chimpanzee species should be classified under the Homo genus). Art, language, agriculture and war have been variously proposed as the characteristics that make humans unique and set them apart from apes and other animals. Diamond treats each of them separately, discusses possible precursor behaviors in various animals, and proposes mechanisms by which these features might have evolved to their more sophisticated forms that we see in humans today. He talks about bonobos using language, elephants making art (that was successfully used to dupe art critics into thinking some modernist painter painted), ants using fungi and aphids as 'farmers', gorillas murdering rival gorillas and other behaviors and links them to evolutionary advantages. He ends the book by discussing genocides throughout history and rings a note of alarm and caution over what he sees as rapid destruction of environment. Throughout the book he dispels numerous myths (such as the ancient civilization were environmentally friendly and were peaceful). He is a very persuasive writer and knows how to construct a convincing argument using hard science but without using too much jargon that would otherwise cause laypeople to lose interest. As a scientist in training myself, I find this ability admirable. Even though the book was written more than 20 years ago it doesn't feel outdated at all. Some of the genetic relations discussed at the beginning of the book have been more refined now (for e.g., bonobos, which are referred to as pygmy chimpanzees in the book, are now considered to be a separate species) and recent genetic analysis confirmed interbreeding and intermixing of Neanderthals with modern humans, which most likely led to the speedy extinction of the former. If you wish to embark on a fascinating journey through the sands of time and want to learn about language trees, kerosene-drinking martial artists of Indonesia, bowerbirds, micro-civilizations of New Guinea and Jackson Pollock-imitating monkeys, this is the book for you. Thoroughly invigorating read.

The Third Chimpanzee is the second of Jared Diamond’s books I’ve read. The first being Guns, Germs, and Steel. Diamond. Diamond is a lucid writer who, for me, next to Karl Marx, seems to break down the origins of human behavior, political and social relations, and the consequences of our actions in ways we need to understand them.The Third Chimpanzee explains our over three million years of evolution from the pygmy chimpanzee as or closest relatives to the Homo Sapiens we are today. Many of the chapters of the book don’t seem connected, but basically Diamond tries to explain the evolutionary and biological origins of human behavior, from why and how we have sex, to how human language, art, and agriculture evolved, to the dire consequences and benefits of modern civilization and technology.Like a left or right leaning talk show host, Diamond is not about being neutral in his information and history. Though he’s a archeologist, he’s a scientist not afraid to support research with analysis and opinion. His last few chapters could be titled “Warnings,“ in which says: Until our own generation, no one had grounds to worry whether the human generation would survive our enjoy a planet worth living on. Ours is the first generation to be confronted with these questions about its children’s future. We devote much our lives to training our children to support themselves and to get along with other people. Increasingly, we’re asking ourselves whether all those efforts of our might be wasted.This jeremiad comes out of a study of nature, and human history and behavior which shows that we’re not always as rational and self-conscious as we might believe or hope. And because our existence on this planet is certainly not purposed and guided by some outside supreme being who has a place for us when we die, we best use books like The Third Chimpanzee to understand better who we are in relations to one another, and other species for whom must share this planet.This book is not a challenge to read. Like I said, Diamond is a very lucid and sometimes entertaining writer, but The Third Chimpanzee should be read in a study group or evolutionary biology course, because there’s so much information to absorb that it’s difficult to grasp it all if you’re merely reading rather than studying it. At some points Diamond can make almost sweeping generalizations about such topics as adultery and our use of drugs, while other times times he gets very detailed about the origins of human language. In reading this book straight through, I know there’s much that I could go back and read again to better understand. Nevertheless, I found The Third Chimpanzee pretty insightful, though it lacks a central thesis. It makes me interested in possibly reading his latest book, Collapse: How Societies Choose to Fail or Succeed. The last few chapters of Chimpanzee seem to point to what Collapse is about. It’s a challenge to read books like Collapse because the issues addressed and explored are so huge and out of reach for most of us to deal with. But if we remain ignorant of past mistakes, we—as the adage goes— are doomed to repeat them.

Fascinating book! A little dense so it took me a few days to read, but really interesting. In fact, since I started reading this book it seems like every other story I hear on the radio is about evolution, some are even on some of the exact topics in this book (which would be less weird if this book just came out but it was published in 1992.)What convinced me to read it was a tidbit about how one of the very, very few things that are unique to humans is our desire to have sex alone, in private. Most animals do it in public, surrounded by their peers. Sadly, Dr. Diamond doesn't have a really cool explanation beyond that it likely increases the bond between partners which is crucial for raising human children, as they take so friggin long to raise. But meanwhile, I got all sorts of other neat tidbits of info: why are "bad boys" so attractive? Do other animals use drugs? Was farming the beginning of the end for humans? How/when/where did we develop language? Basically this book isn't just about evolution as a fact. It's about the why behind it. Why did humans develop certain abilities, skills, or predilections and how were those things useful to us? Some are quite obvious such as domesticating animals, but others aren't such as murder. He looks at other species for answers which usually demonstrates how things we think are unique to humans really aren't, and it shows how truly useful ideas develop more than once. (Ants actually raise aphids like we raise cattle.) Another undercurrent throughout the books is how we have evolved to the point where we can now destroy ourselves and the whole world. Several times Dr. Diamond mentions his sons, and how he's worried about the future they're inheriting. Reading the book 18 years after publication gives these arguments both more weight and less. The likelihood of nuclear war has lessened, while climate change has accelerated. I would be very interested if they added a new afterward in a newer edition. I wonder what Dr. Diamond thinks of the world today. Interestingly, I came away from this book thinking how much like animals humans are (only 2% difference in DNA between us and chimpanzees). I told my friend T. about it, and she thought of the opposite - how much like humans animals are. (Yes, she is a big PETA supporter.) J. who recommended it was more interested in the history of the human being. It has a broad appeal and many people will get different things out of it.This book will stay with me for quite a while. Whenever I see someone smoking, guys getting into a fight, or a woman being hit on in a bar, I will think of different aspects of Dr. Diamond's theories, and how pretty much everything we do is in an unconscious effort to pass along our genes.

I feel kinda bad giving this three stars, because I probably would have given it four or five stars if I read it in 1992, but some things just haven't held up. The style is a little egocentric, as when Jared Diamond feels entitled to contradict research based on his hunches and guesses to form his own theories in a field he's not really an expert in. It just feels a little long-winded and scattered in comparison to the sleek, concise pop-sci books being published today. Even Diamond's own hefty tome Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies, which grew out of one of the chapters of The Third Chimpanzee, surpasses this earlier work in cohesiveness and is better grounded in research. However, I enjoyed the discussion of sexuality and the human life cycle in terms of evolution and natural selection - this was great content I haven't come across before. I also enjoyed the discussion of the Great Leap, in which humanity was transformed into the species we are today by the development of language (according to Diamond) and the explanation of how Homo sapiens differs from Neanderthals. And I really do appreciate the books conclusion: Diamond's earnest plea for humanity to learn from our past mistakes and preserve our environment. It's well-argued and passionate. But again, many of these research areas have advanced significantly since 1992 and I found myself feeling like it was worthless to read in this book about, for example, DNA and genetic sequencing. And what really rubbed me the wrong way was Diamond's high-horse moralizing about "drug abuse". Michael Pollan has a far more open-minded and interesting take on why humans have always sought out mind-altering substances in his fantastic book The Botany of Desire: A Plant's-Eye View of the World. Diamond, writing at the height of the "War on Drugs," would lump crack addicts in with Native Americans who used ayahuasca or peyote for spiritual journeys in his discussion of "drug abuse" as self-destructive behavior. From an evolutionary perspective, I believe that altering our consciousness to achieve new perspectives is a fascinating human behavior that is not purely self-destructive. In some cultures, in fact, it is seen as self-instructive or self-constructive. Perhaps this could better explain this trait's survival as we evolved.

Human beings are remarkable creatures, unique on Earth, some believe unique in the universe. But what makes us what we are? Why have we developed art and science when other species seem not to? And are we unique in our negative capacities - drug abuse, war and environmental destruction? Diamond looks at the evolution of mankind, the third chimpanzee, with particular reference to those traits.The only trouble with reading books like this in our age is that misanthropy seems to be the fashion. Seeing mankind as a venal, destructive parasite without redeeming features is the cause celebre of the modern world. This lends a somewhat bitter taste to this as with many other volumes. Fortunately, it's more toward the back of the book, but still it's there. Diamond tells a fascinating story about what various forms of evidence can tell us about the rise of man and his spread across the world, but his biases tend to make him blind to other views. So, for example, when he projects the rate of species destruction in the future, he treats the rate as at best linear, at worst proportionate to the human population - it never occurs to him that as societies have become richer they have become more concerned about environmental issues, something which explains the much lower rate of species extinction in Europe in recent centuries. Similarly, when claiming that hunter-gatherer societies eat just as well as agricultural ones, he misses the point that agricultural societies free up large chunks of their populace to do other things - including writing books about how terrible we all are. Here and there Diamond also grabs the odd "fact" out of thin air, such as that sexual inequality is a product of agricultural societies. After chapters where he has explained in some detail why human females are unique in going through menopause, it seems jarring to throw out a statement like that without either proof or any kind of theory as to why it might be so, which means it comes across as a desperate attempt to ram in a point from a list he had accumulated before writing the book.All the negativity aside, the book reads well and gives an interesting insight into where we come from. It's not exhaustive - I'm still looking for a book which explains our sexual relations in anthropological terms, for example - but as a starting point it's worth considering.

Jared Diamond has lived a fascinating life and has clearly enjoyed applying his curiosity and experience to the big questions. What would a physiologist with a side interest in ornithology have to say about the past, present and future of the human race? And what does this have to do with the tendency of humans to take drugs? In this book, Diamond writes a series of extended abstracts for the books he wrote later, such as collapse and guns, germs and steel. So. While a huge amount of ground is covered, most of the chapters are in fact relatively brief, but the span itself requires some perseverance.The main gist of the book is what makes humans form their closest genetic cousins the chimps. Yet genes seem to have a minor part to play, compared to the cultural innovations that have occurred. I liked the description of humanities gauntlet, the critical period during which language, tools and art were primed for the diaspora which saw Asia, Europe and Australia populated, and their major megafauna wiped out. This tendency toward environmental destruction, and destruction of our own species, is covered in later chapters, as extrapolation to the fate of our species is examined. This stuff is compelling reading. It is not heavily referenced, making it readable for lay readers, but the seriousness of Diamond's theses suggests that this is perhaps required (the extensive suggested reading doesn't seem to feel adequate somehow). The broad scope of diamonds interest makes verification for the lay reader difficult: where I have read on related topics, such as Tim Flannery's Future Eaters, the conclusions seem to agree (I also assume these guys know each other), but there are so many areas to check up on, I am left needing to believe his version is reliable. I am happy that everything seems internally consistent.Given that Diamond is still publishing - I received his most recent book on what we can learn from indigenous peoples for a recent birthday - I am happy to assume he is on to something. Either that, or it's a great way to read across the breadth of questions and hypotheses about the intriguing journey humanity has taken to get here.

Summary: This was a fascinating book that, despite being older, included some new information and made me think about things in new ways.Happy Darwin Day everyone! Since today is the anniversary of the publication of The Origin of Species, it seemed like the perfect day to talk about Jared Diamond's The Third Chimpanzee. The third chimpanzee, of course, is us and in this book Diamond explores the things we have in common with (the other two) chimps and the things that we typically think make us unique.In addition to the obvious topical connection, this was the perfect book for Darwin Day because of the author's dedication to answering even potentially touchy questions with science. As the author points out, answering questions such as why Europeans invaded the Americas, rather than the other way around, doesn't have to lead to racist answers. It can, in fact replace racist assumptions with far more politically correct, scientifically accurate, fascinating facts.Happily, even though this book was published in 1991 and sometimes posed open questions I'm know we've answered now, I learned some new things. The author also did a great job sharing information I knew in ways that made me think about things differently. For instance, although it's become common knowledge that chimps are our most closely related species, I thought it was interesting to think about the fact that we're their most closely related species too.The author did occasionally came across to me as trying really hard to be politically correct but falling just a little short on issues of gender, race, or, in one case, weight. In general though, I was impressed by how well the author handled the touchy subjects he addressed. He also did what I thought was a great job with the science, explaining concepts clearly and engagingly. Overall, I'd recommend Diamond's Guns, Germs, and Steel over the The Third Chimpanzee, but this was also an interesting read.This review was originally posted on Doing Dewey

We human beings share 98 percent of our genes with chimpanzees. Yet humans are the dominant species on the planet - having founded civilizations and religions, developed intricate and diverse forms of communication, learned science, built cities, and created breathtaking works of art - while chimps remain animals concerned primarily with the basic necessities of survival. What is it about that two percent difference in DNA that has created such a divergence between evolutionary cousins? In this fascinating, provocative, passionate, funny, endlessly entertaining work, renowned Pulitzer Prize-winning author and scientist Jared Diamond explores how the extraordinary human animal, in a remarkably short time, developed the capacity to rule the world . . . and the means to irrevocably destroy it. Diamond explores concepts relating to the animal origins of human behavior, including cultural characteristics and those features often regarded as particularly unique to humans. It further explores the question of how Homo sapiens came to dominate its closest relatives, such as chimpanzees, and why one group of humans (Eurasians) came to dominate others (Indigenous peoples of the Americas, for example).One of the interesting things I learned from this book: there is a field of study called "Linguistic Paleoentology". It is a linguistic and subsidiary historical discipline that uses linguistic data to derive information about the history and geographical location of the speakers of a particular language. Linguistic paleontology also aims to obtain information about the material and spiritual culture of the speakers in the preliterary period. Overall, this book is a fascinating read and recommended to anyone interested in the anthropological history of our species. Over five major sections, Diamond educates the reader on the core issues of evolutionary biology, explores these issues as they related to timeless moral questions, and examines the role our biology plays in determining our future.

The book was a bit too anecdotal for my liking; there were too many personal stories and opinions in a book that I assumed would be about science/history. Even though there were some interesting ideas and points brought up, they were done in a really conversational tone (which is often a good thing, but that I didn't like in this book), and lines like the ones below made me lose trust in the author around half way through the book.My wife and I have been barraging my sons from early infancy onwards with grammatically correct English questions as well as statements [...] Today's samples from Max and Joshua include 'Where it is? , 'What that letter is? , 'What the handle can do? , and 'What you did with it?'Just imagine savage hunters, exhausted from searching for nuts and chasing wild animals, suddenly gazing for the first time at a fruit-laden orchard or a pasture full of sheep. How many milliseconds do you think it took those hunters to appreciate the advantages of agriculture?On 26 June I was sitting in a Boeing 747 jet, reading the magazines and catching up on the wonders of Western civilization. [...] I leafed through the first magazine. It fell open to a page with a photograph of a tough-looking man on horseback chasing cows, and the name of a brand of cigarette in large letters below. The American in me knew what the photograph was about, but part of me was still in the jungle, looking at that photo naively. That proximity of wolves and sheep spelt T-R-O-U-B-L-E.I think I sort of understand what he might have been trying to do with the book, I just didn't enjoy it. Many points were repeated several times in different ways (often in an emotive style, with populist phrases) and there were so many different topics covered in such a fast and loose way that it was hard to get anything too meaningful from it. It did serve as a great book for me to find other things to read about though, so I guess that was good.

Anyone who's read Diamond's Guns, Germs, and Steel will know roughly what to expect from his first book: big, wide-ranging, eclectic ideas all drawn into a discussion of a single theme.Should you be wondering, the 'Third Chimpanzee' of the title is Man, and the book is an attempt to look at our evolutionary history in the hope it will shed some light on our otherwise-mystifying tendencies towards self-destruction.The book is logically laid-out and developed and most of the individual chapters are fascinating and could stand alone, although the further Diamond strays from his own field the more questionable some of his assumptions and conclusions seem: particularly odd is the section on SETI research, in which he concludes a) that civilisations like our own are likely to destroy themselves before developing interstellar travel and b) any 'flying saucers' (the author's - revealing - choice of words, not mine) are likely to be crewed by extraterrestrial analogues of ourselves - ie. space-going conquistadors and destroyers of less advanced cultures. They can't both be true...As the book progresses from evolutionary science - which I would say was very nearly required reading for any budding SF writers trying to develop their own alien cultures - to a study of the ecological impact of civilisation, the tone grows perceptibly more serious, and towards the end it does seem like the book is going to become a full-blown jeremiad. The grounds for optimism Diamond ultimately presents seem rather trifling given the weight of evidence he's already produced, showing what an essentially violent and destructive creature a modern human being is.Some of the key arguments of Guns, Germs and Steel get rehearsed here, but there's enough new and different material here to make this a worthwhile read in its own right. Not the most cheery thing I've ever read, but credible and eye-opening nevertheless.

This is the launching point for Diamond's other great, better known books. The early part of the book provides a quick description of human evolution, and explains the title of the book. The chimpanzees are our closest relatives within the animal kingdom, and according to Diamond, an unbiased taxonomy would call us just another species of chimpanzee. The first species is the common chimpanzee, the second is the pygmy chimpanzee, which is now known as the bonobo, and the third species is now called homo sapiens (erroneously, according to Diamond). After giving a quick review of human evolution, he describes the various differences between humans and the other chimpanzees. He tries to explain the evolutionary causes for the differences between humans and the other apes in sexual behavior and anatomy (which he explores later in a book called Why Sex is Fun). He then introduces the other topics that he devotes so much attention to later. He anticipates Guns, Germs, and Steel by discussing the various geographical factors that gave Eurasia such an advantage over America. He then anticipates Collapse by discussing how some societies have abused their environment and thereby caused their own demise.Although Diamond's later books cover these themes in much more depth, The Third Chimpanzee shows how Diamond relates all these themes to each other. Diamond does not yet have a book that explores human evolution in more depth (except for Why Sex is Fun, which is about the evolution of sexuality), but there are many other books about evolution. But for the other topics, Diamond's later books are much more focused and detailed. But The Third Chimpanzee is still a worthwhile read for anyone who has already read his other books, or for anyone who isn't ready to explore these themes at such depth.

Having previously read Jared Diamond's more famous Guns Germs and Steel, I can't help but reflect on this book in comparison. I gave that book five stars and this book three, but that may say more about the order in which I read them than the books themselves, for in truth they're remarkably similar. The Third Chimpanzee starts out in a slightly different vein, talking more about early human evolution and our divergence from common and pygmy chimps (making us the third chimp species), then shifts over into various human societies' destruction of their environments over the years. It's this latter portion that Diamond later expanded into Guns Germs and Steel and Collapse. Though I understand Diamond is trying to show how our genes have led to some of our more disastrous traits (genocide, destruction of the environment, etc.), it feels a little disjointed. I like Guns Germs and Steel's more focused approach, but for anyone who likes Diamond's other books enough, who wants to read a slightly shorter book to understand his points, or who has a thing for chimpanzees, this book's for you.

After reading some of Jared Diamond's other books (such as Collapse and his most famous, Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies), I picked up this older one, from the nineties.This book discusses why humans are so different from the other Hominidae (chimps/bonobos, orangutans and gorillas), and in which ways we are so similar; starting of with the tired factoid that we share 98% or our DNA with them (it seems the number is a bit less though, 96% or so. Cfg. a cucumber, which is 96% water -- those few % do matter!)Diamond goes through many different fields (paleontology, linguistics, biology, sociology etc.), and the main conclusion is there are non-human precursors to just about any human behavior, but that the quantitative difference is so big that it becomes qualitative. And since it's a Diamond book, there are plenty of anecdotes about New Guinea.The books is interesting, but a bit outdated (e.g., non-Africans do have Neanderthal DNA); a more serious complaint that also applies to Guns, Germs and Steel is that the conclusions that Diamond draws are partly based on what he would like to be true, stretching the evidence a bit too far. Or focusing in on some interesting details, but that have little to do with the subject of the book, such as a lengthy discussion of the origins of Indo-European languages (also a part where Diamond does perhaps a bit too much 'original research')Anyhow, despite that, interesting book.

I can't honestly put this book on the "read" shelf, but that's where it will have to live until I can bear to pick it up again. That time may never come. This pop science jibber-jabber had me sailing along with it, going along with the egregious jumps over nuanced scientific discovery in the name of calling it "pop." Typical of books of this genre - the complex data is always glossed over and we're left with the "big picture."Then I finished the first chapter. Mr. Diamond decided to get into it with me right then and there, in the concluding paragraphs of his first 20 pages. At first he presents thought-provoking questions about the divisions between humans and animals - where those lines are drawn, why we draw them, what criteria we have used to divide ourselves from our animal kin, etc. THEN he proceeds to condemn scientific research on chimpanzees because humans, as it turns out, are the third species of chimpanzees (title, duh). Not only that, but research on any other non-human primate is not up for grabs either. Now this will probably make me a target for animal rights activists or zealots of some kind, but some of the greatest discoveries in medicine and science were made because of animals. Some of the humblest discoveries as well. I can agree to disagree, but it would have been nice for Diamond to have saved his soapbox wallop for later in the book. Lull me in with a false sense of security, even for a hundred pages, before you pull out the lightning flashes and thunder rumbles about the great modern sin of animal research.I hope Jared Diamond never gets brain cancer. He probably won't ever want to get a headache again either because the best pain relievers were tested first on animals, including primates. Sigh.

A wonderful profound and wide-ranging deep-thinking book. Humans are genetically so close to chimpanzees that objectively we are them. We differ most from chimpanzees in sexual behavior, sexual traits and sexual physiology. Some other differences unique to the human animal seem to be language, art, addiction and maybe genocide, although some of these also are seen in non-humans.I loved the overview of the recent past, from the end of the last ice age when culture escalated. The Cro-Magnons may have genocided the Neanderthals as migrations out of Africa exploded over the earth. The effects of agriculture and domesticated animals on humans were insightful theories. Humans in the Eurasian steppes had the advantage of domesticated horses and demolished other conquered cultures because of their horses. Dogs have evolved into psychological geniuses who are now the masters of humans who nurture and love them equally with their human children.Only herd animals can be domesticated and only a few of them. The author presents brilliant fresh ideas of how geography affected human domestication of animals and also of plants. Domestic agriculture presented the opportunity for government (dictator, king) to invent itself along with taxes which was impossible under a hunter-gatherer society. There were good ideas about different societies and some of the advantages and disadvantages of stable agricultural societies versus mobile forager-hunter societies.The author has presented the effect of geography on culture as no one else before. He has a different genre of mind which is refreshing and intriguing. I loved his ideas and his writing style which kept me continually desirous of picking up his book at every opportunity, in spite of its thought-provoking power.

This is the spirit in which I dedicate this book to my young sons and their generations. If we learn from the past that I have traced, our future may be brighter than that of the other two chimpanzeesAs a person who doesn't have any evolutionary biology background, in other word, a total amateur, I enjoyed reading this book. They decided to use an easy to understand language to explain complicated things without making it sound dumb. They explained every bit of information to its smallest terminology. After all, the book was made for young people. It's written on the cover.It managed to make me do some retrospective thinking toward what I've done with my lifestyle that actually had a major impact toward the environment. They explained about how close are we to our related species, and what exactly made us so different than them. They also told me how catastrophic the impact of the development of our civilization so far. The extinction of gigantic animal in several places, until their descendants finally evolved the fear of our species as a way to survive. How brutal was that?I made bad reviews, I know. It's so easy to impress me, but this book literally made me want to buy and read another book about evolution.

An enjoyable book.Diamond is charting a nice story for the rise of homo-sapiens (third chimpanzee in his terminology). There are some outdated information in parts of the book:For example, it is now well accepted that 3% of human DNA for people from outside Africa is Neanderthal's DNA while Diamond dismisses any possibility of inter-breeding between the new sapiens (cro-magnons) and neanderthals.Another example is the certainty about how did early sapiens who arrived to the America's arrive (through a bridge between Siberia and Alaska) and then spread (on foot using a corridor in the ice sheets that runs north-south which was open around 11000years ago). Both of these points are contested.Concerning the origins, there are rival theories based on the idea that ancient western Europeans could have crossed the ice-fringed Atlantic by boat or that Melanesians could have sailed across the Pacific to South America, and then migrated across Central America to colonise North America. The recent findings of a child with western-European DNA in Siberia may also mean that the origin of the hunters who crossed to America may have not been only east-Asian but with some western-European people in the mix. http://www.independent.co.uk/news/sci...Moreover, there are some theories that suggest that the passing from north to south happened along the shore mainly and that early Americans were naval people.Nevertheless, these points (and the few others) did not affect the main message of the book.

This book is clearly now a bit dated. But even so, it's not so dated that it's message is invalid. I learned so much from this book. Every chapter I started out with my curiosity piqued to discover how "human" characteristics really aren't so human after all. By the end of each chapter I was fascinated by the extent of human behavior that's demonstrated in animals, and the evolutionary benefits of these actions. We're not so unique, us humans. Monkeys have a primitive form of language, bowerbirds have art, ants have a sort of agriculture, nesting birds cheat on their "marriages". I also found it predictable & understandable that exotics like pigs & reindeer introduced suddenly to unsuspecting remote islands within decades completely destroyed their resource base & were left starving w/ nothing remaining to eat. It's not just us that promoted the extinction of 100s of species, but the rats we brought w/ us, which small mammals & birds were completing unprepared for in for example New Zealand and Hawaii. But at the same time it is our fault for accelerating this environmental degradation process nearing the point of no return. We introduce exotics, deforest, hunt, develop, take over.Jared Diamond is optimistic about the human ability to change all of their actions & move in the direction of stability w/ the Earth. He has faith that politicians worldwide will put aside their personal desires for wealth & power to look long-term at the bigger picture.

I didn't think this as good as Guns Germs and Steel, and in places it is now starting to show its age, having first been published 20 years ago. The author has lots of interesting views to put across, though I didn't find too much that was novel. At times he reminded me of someone giving a PowerPoint presentation, frequently telling us what he is going to tell us later rather than just getting on with it.In an odd approach, Diamond is boldly suggesting that humans should be regarded as the third chimpanzee (fair enough as a position, particularly one selected deliberately to provoke) but why then does he generally fail to include humans in either apes or animals, both of which are a much easier sell and, in context, pretty uncontroversial, even default positions?For a scientist, he is also a bit too keen on making assertions that things are obvious, or listing some evidence which tends to suggest something and then stating that something as a fact. His boldness in asserting that the atomic bomb attacks on Japan were genocide, without real discussion, is a view that is not unique to him, but I found it rather removed focus from his more general and illuminating discussion on humans' genocide and similar patterns among other animals.These niggles rather detract from what is otherwise an interesting and broad overview of humans and our similarities with and differences from other animals.

The best way that I can describe this book is that it puts human beings in their appropriate context. What I mean by that is that Diamond is adamant about questioning all the ways in which we have claimed to be a unique unprecedented develop on the face of the earth. This can be appreciated from the get go as seen from his title, which foreshadows the brilliant argument by which he shows that biologically speaking we are more alike to the two subspecies of chimpanzees than they are to gorillas, our next closest kin. It is in this vein that Diamond continues to explore the animal precursors to almost all the things by which we claimed to be unique: language, tools, art, murder, etc. He similarly advocates for the importance of studying how we fit into the history of the world in order to avoid the present course to collapse to which we seem to be heading. He analyses the spread of humans, the key points of our evolution that put us into a course of world conquest and the difficult relationship we’ve had with our environment from the beginning. In all these discussions Diamond not only gives ample evidence but at the same time maintains the interest of the reader, even through some of the most gruesome aspects of our tendency for genocide. I cannot recommend this book highly enough to every thinking human being as it is vital for our understanding of our own place in the planet.

The author is one of the better known anthropologist writers (Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies). Here is address how humans are similar and different to the animals the are closest to our DNAs.While secularists read Diamond like gospel, Christians who see a role for God in the origin of man can still benefit from Diamond's knowledge. Be forewarned that you will learn way more about chimps and other primates than you probably ever wanted to, unless you have a clinical curiosity for their mating habits. Diamond does lean green but he is not as dogmatic as some secularists who seem to feel the earth would be better of without any humans.As an aside to this book, Diamond is big on evolution and as to be expected ignores the presence of God in the creation and development of mankind. However he fails to address the fact that civilizations that embrace secular humanism are among the worst for mankind as we can see from the disasters of Stalin's Russia and Mao's China. Even modern post-religious Europe is a culture that is not sustainable as proven by their self-selected negative population. The evolution of man has worked best in societies who embrace Christian values. Lacking this, thing go downhill. Moral relativism makes for a poor foundation for the long term prosperity of society.

I haven't had the pleasure of reading GGAS yet, so I can't use that as a Jared Diamond touchstone like other reviewers here have, but I found The Third Chimpanzee to be a generally well-constructed, readable synthesis, even if it's a bit over-broad. Although its years do show at times (e.g. in the chapter on nuclear warfare, an arena that has shifted rather significantly since publication), most of the material cited seems to hold up pretty well.Diamond is at his encyclopedic best in his sweeping anthropological surveys — which, fortunately, comprise most of the book. It's only when Diamond divagates from this territory that the book becomes problematic. In the section on sexual behavior, for example, he (among other dubious instances of, well, prudishness) cites a cosmo-mag survey (or sales numbers, I don’t recall) to prove that large penis size could not possibly have arisen from female sexual selection. Later, he purports to know that the search for intelligent extraterrestrial life will be inevitably fruitless because somehow self-annihilation (nuclear or otherwise) is in his view the inexorable destiny of all intelligent life — and yet, strangely, he doesn't ever earnestly apply this same fatalism to humanity.Despite bewildering arguments like these that occasionally gurgle up, the book is great. The linguistic anthropology in the latter chapters is particularly fascinating.

I love Jared Diamond's writing. Every time I read one of his books, it resonates so clearly that I can't help but enjoy his thoughts tremendously. In The Third Chimpanzee, Diamond ranges widely in his thoughts of this odd third chimpanzee (us) and sometimes goes in rather unexpected places. Some highlights include how testes correlate with number of partners in sex and how public/private sex is, and the arts are a social method of sexual selection. The migration of some of human kind can be studied by the transformation of proto-Indo-European language, but he includes a fervent discussion of the loss of human languages as the few powerful languages consolidate their power and their populations on the world.He includes wonderful comments on genocide in chimps and genocide in humans across time. How we have permission to kill "them," but we must attempt to refrain from killing "us."Most disjointed was his theories of life on other worlds, which covers a part of a chapter. What is most interesting is the echoes of his other writings you can hear in this book. Echoes in the sense that it doesn't matter if the book came before or after this 2006 publication. His themes have remained constant: Ecological collapse, success of an area and the people controlling that area based on resources, and domesticate-able plant and animal species.

The beginning of this book was well written and fascinating to read. There were actually witty remarks that had me amused in parts, which you wouldn't expect from something so scientific. The explanations for how humans developed behaviors and the comparisons with chimps and other animals in order to help with those explanations were easy to associate with and really helped with the taking in of the information. The text didn't treat the readers like award winning scientists, but it didn't dumb everything up for the ignorant either.By the last 100 pages of the book I became frustrated, however. As long as the book was actually doing what was expected of it and comparing us to chimps and explaining our evolution, I was content, but once it switched to how we were destroying our environment, it became less of "this is why we do what we do" to "this is how the demise of the world will come about." There wasn't even really a connection to humans beyond that we killed things. I'm not saying it wasn't well written, but it simply wasn't as mind-catching the way the first 200 pages were.Definitely worth the read for the amazing revelations put forward about human nature and the ways of some animals. I know that I will forever have friends check the lengths of their middle fingers against their spouses from this point onward.

The first section of this book (on human evolution) was an enjoyable refresher of my physical anthropology courses in college. The second section was a bit more difficult for me to get through, however, simply because Diamond's language was so incredibly heteronormative. I realize that my objections are purely semantic, and I actually found much of the material to be quite informative, but I can only read phrases like "...of the opposite sex" so many times before I start to get annoyed. Indeed, Diamond's only mention of non-heterosexual activity was to illustrate the promiscuity of bonobos! It would have been nice if he would have at least acknowledged that not all humans are driven by the instinct to reproduce with members of the opposite sex in order to pass along their genes.That being said, I'm glad that I decided to stick with it, because I had relatively no qualms with the rest of the book (although I didn't buy into his myopic theory about why people use drugs), and found it to be quite enlightening. In fact, I am now hoping to read all of Diamond's books at some point (with the possible exception of his book on sex, which I suspect would be even more heteronormative than this one). Over all, this book provided a substantial amount of food for thought, and if it weren't for the aforementioned issues, I would have happily given it five stars.

Just got around to reading this earlier Diamond book, and since it was published in '92, it's understandably a bit dated. Notably the debate about whether modern humans have Neanderthal DNA was still unresolved (we do). It's no less than the entire past and future of humanity that he attempts to address here, and it's not surprising that he felt the need to more deeply explore some aspects of that wide ranging topic in later books, so this book introduces and covers some of the material that is further expanded upon in Guns, Germs, and Steel and Collapse. In particular, his theory on the biogeographic factors that were the driving force behind the success of some civilizations and the failure of others is well-stated and convincing. As usual, his clear explanations and engaging writing are impressive, and I learned a few things I had not come across in other books along these lines. So I enjoyed this one quite a bit in spite of minor issues, though I'd recommend also reading the above-mentioned follow-ups for a more in depth treatment of this fascinating subject matter.

Not as good as Guns, Germs, and Steel, but still worth a read...probably. I didn't feel like I was learning awesome new things the whole time, as I did with the other. And some of the same ground is covered, or maybe I've covered it elsewhere.Eh, it's just not as well written, and it was published earlier so we'll have to cut him some slack. His conclusions don't follow as logically from his explanations, he repeats whole phrases from earlier chapters, like a textbook trying to drill a concept into your head or (more likely) like someone who hasn't read the previous chapter recently. Also, he picks out some good and bad human traits that (supposedly) separate us from other animals and discusses them. The bad ones are things like genocide and drug addiction. Not exactly equally bad, are they? I actually folded down a couple of pages to mark odd uses of words, like "lacks" as a noun, but I'm not going to look them up now.Fittingly, this review is badly organized.P.S. I just checked his wikipedia page for some fact and found that, between Guns, Germs, and Steel and The Third Chimpanzee, he wrote a book called Why is Sex Fun?" I think the answer is "So you'll keep doing it", but there's bound to be more to it than that. Intriguing.

This book is full of fascinating information, yet I give it only 3 stars ("liked it") because the author it too scattered. It feels like he wanted to write at least 2 different books (which he subsequently did). I think his primary argument that the characteristics that make us unique arguably have animal precursors (e.g. rudimentary language of the vervets). However, his prose wanders. For example, when discussing agriculture, he points out that New World ants have indeed a system of agriculture, domesticating both plants and animals. Nevertheless, he then strays and devotes several pages to the argument whether agricultural or hunter-gather societies are better off. This latter section, though interesting, can be better discussed elsewhere. I also don’t understand the need for the chapter on other life in outer space. Sometimes, too, his writing is hyperbolic (e.g. progressed at an infinitely slow rate) and his logic unconvincing (e.g. saying that because we can estimate Malaysia has lost half of its fish species, we can assume the same percentage of loss in other species). I would prefer more counterarguments or at least footnotes along the way. Otherwise, it is an enjoyable book with important lessons for all of us. I look forward to reading Collapse in the near future.

Even as someone who knows we share all but something like 1.6% of our genetic material with chimpanzees, and as someone who isn't floored by the notion that by some taxonomic standards we could basically considered a particularly smart kind of chimpanzee, I still found a lot of thought-provoking and controversial material in this book. It concerns many of the facets of what differences that 1.6% makes--what makes us human. From Diamond's perspective our abilities to cooperate and communicate, to transmit knowledge across generations, is at times outweighed by our less savory characteristics: namely, our enjoyment of torturing each other, our propensity for drug abuse, and our (unprecedented in other animals) tendency to destroy our environment. He shows how even many of those characteristics have physiological roots in our animal brains. The chapters on language and art were some of the most fascinating, discussing whether animals can be said to create "art" or have "language" in instances where they appear to do so, and in the case of language in humans whether there is a hard-wired propensity for using grammatical rules (as evidenced in the similar grammatical structures of "creole" languages.) The range of perspective covered here is amazing.

The only answer to why we've come together as a society is our big brains and our ways of sharing our knowledge on to the next person, but if science proves that we are 98% chimpanzee what are the differences from our ways and the ways of chimpanzees. Jared Diamond has created another wonderful book that is not too complicated to read but shows how complicated and explains thoroughly how in depth evolution is. The author shows the differences between man and ape caveman and human etc. The reader makes it very realistic in his language, such as comparing teens self destructive behavior such as alcohol to birds who grow long tails which could slow them down to the point of getting caught and eaten. This book shows why women live longer than men. This book makes the reader think differently about the human race in general by grabbing the readers attention and making us remember life as it was ten thousand years ago compared to us now completely oblivious to surviving. Anyone who does not know all they want about human society or wants a book I suppose no one but biologists know prove to any ordinary person thirsty for knowledge that there is more to our evolutions from our so similar ancestors.

A definite mixed bag. I LOVED his subsequent "Guns, Germs, and Steel," but this one is far less compelling, partly b/c it seems cobbled together from disparate articles at times, but primarily b/c his reductionist tendencies are far more in evidence, and far more offensive, since he's dealing with areas of the human experience that are far less amenable to scientific (or even philosophical) reduction ("Guns" deals with the science behind the rise of civilizations and the West's bloody triumph in that "race"; this book is more about the science behind general human phenomena like sex, murder, art, etc.). At some point maybe I'll detail some of the book's good stuff (and there are definitely a lot of diamonds in the rough here), but for now I'd say that it doesn't add much to the imposing legacy of "Guns" or to the study of human behavior in general (though it's an interesting launching point for lay folk like me, I reckon). I suspect the follow-up to "Guns" ("Collapse") is a better example of this chimp book's strong suits (i.e., the later chapters that discuss why civilizations collapse, particularly from an environmental standpoint), and I may well read it as a result.

So far it's not really doing anything much for me. For one thing it incurs in one of my pet peeves: the author talks about evolution in a misleading way that can make the layman believe that evolution happens with a design in mind, so to speak, thus substituting the designing God of creationism with an unknown force of nature called Evolution that does exactly the same. Evolution does not have a design in mind - mutations happen, some of thsoe mutations are better at leaving copies of themselves so those mutated traits get passed along to the next generations. And so on and so forth, blindly, for thousands and thousands and THOUSANDS of years. Obviously the writer knows it but he resorts to simplificate his exposition and writing in ways that can be highly misleading to unsuspecting readers. Aside from that I fail to see any original ideas in the book, except for his allegations that chimps ought to be better treated because we share so much of our genome with them. He might have a point there. The rest of the content is not new to me and not particularly well written (but I am reading him in spanish so this last part might be the translator's fault)

A good book, and worth reading. It mostly discusses two characteristics the author views as uniquely human: the tendency to commit genocide, and the tendency to wipe out one resource base after another when moving from place to place. The basic message seems to be that humans aren't doing anything new, and haven't become more evil over the past ten thousand years or so, but that our numbers and technology have advanced to the point where we absolutely must curb these inborn behaviors now. The Red Queen: Sex and the Evolution of Human Nature covered a lot of the early evolutionary stuff in more detail, and Diamond's own Collapse: How Societies Choose to Fail or Succeed expands a lot on the environmental destruction, but this book is a very manageable and interesting introduction to the same material. I definitely recommend it.

If you, like me, approached this book looking for an explanation of our evolution from apes to our current condition; you may find yourself with mixed feelings. You can easily divide this book in two parts, the chapters that are great, easy to read involving the evolution process and the chapters that are related to Diamond opinion on different subjects (human genocides, nuclear war, sex, etc).On the first ones I really enjoyed is explanation on the newest discoveries and theories about where we come from and how we evolved as we did, why agriculture and animal domestication flourished in the old world but lingered in the new world and finally the explanation of our cause in the extinctions of the big mammals from the past. This is the part that I really liked and hoped to see more in this book. The second part is more difficult to read and felt more like his own personal opinion on the reasons and possible outcomes of our way of life. Although nuclear holocaust is an interesting topic this is not why I started reading this book. Having said that, it is a really good book, with interesting theories and very accessible to non specialists.
